executive_summary: Once regarded as quackery by the American Medical Association, chiropractic care has transformed into a mainstream medical treatment option. While the field still lacks conclusive medical research, private insurers' growing coverage of treatments has strengthened patient access. Patients' uptake of chiropractic care has also been rising as more people seek drug-free or alternative therapies to traditional care methods. Steady growth was disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic as patient volumes dropped, creating long care backlogs. While practices have seen patient numbers recover, cost pressures, inflation and labor shortages continue to create challenges.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pandemic introduced unprecedented disruption to chiropractic clinics
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While chiropractic care was considered essential during the pandemic, allowing practices to continue providing treatments, patient volumes dropped as pandemic concerns kept most people from receiving discretionary medical services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Chiropractors face struggles adjusting to a post-Covid environment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Federal funding available through the Provider Relief Fund helped practices mitigate revenue losses associated with drop-off in patients. Some practices received a bump in patients as pandemic concerns subsided, with patients reporting back and neck pain from long stretches of working from beds, couches and countertops. Delayed chiropractic treatments created long backlogs of appointments in 2021, allowing chiropractic clinics to recoup pandemic losses.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: New challenges unfolded for chiropractic clinics in 2022
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Pent-up demand and pandemic relief funding fizzled out. High rates of burnout and pandemic-related stressors exacerbated staffing shortages occurring pre-COVID. Other nonclinical employees sought jobs with more flexible work environments or higher pay. Hiring challenges pressure practices to raise wages to attract and retain employees.
Rising costs for supplies force clinics to raise exam fees or absorb the extra cost. Higher costs for patients pressure them to rethink discretionary medical spending.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consolidation in healthcare begins reshaping chiropractic care
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consolidation seen across the healthcare sector is trickling into chiropractic clinics. A fragmented chiropractic field gives way to mergers and acquisitions (M&A). A combination of labor shortages, a changing reimbursement landscape, tech adoption and cost pressures are driving forces behind consolidation.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Realigned perceptions about chiropractor treatments will foster competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To capitalize on increasing positive perceptions, industry associations will continue to support research and play a crucial role in promoting the benefits of chiropractic treatment. Individual firms are expected to increase advertising expenditure as well.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A changing clinic structure brings lower costs, more clients and increases profit margins
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Industry structure is changing from a fragmented one with a predominance of sole-practitioner clinics to multidisciplinary clinics or group practices. Large group practices can more easily keep more patient referrals in-house. These new clinic structures permit the spread of advertising, malpractice insurance and office leases over a more extensive revenue base and have the resources to adopt new cost-saving technology and equipment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increases in insurance coverage and healthcare inflation will bolster performance
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The chiropractor services industry generates most of its revenue through out-of-pocket payments. Rising per capita disposable income will enable more consumers to seek chiropractic treatments routinely.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Substitute services for those with doubts about chiropractors may balance innovations that attract others
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Other practitioners (massage therapists, physical therapists, osteopaths, sports medicine specialists, general practitioners, acupuncturists services, nurse practitioners, surgeons) can assist with musculoskeletal conditions and provide substitute services. And products (over-the-counter medicines, CBD oil (cannabidiol) can treat some back pain. These services and products may keep potential clients at bay. Small technology-based hardware and software innovations improve services while machines can replace manual adjustments and workstations perform sophisticated body analysis and lasers for therapy to help provide care.

industry_definition: Chiropractors are licensed healthcare professionals specializing in the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of disorders related to the musculoskeletal system, particularly the spine.

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid
threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: Consolidation is reshaping how chiropractors deliver care. Cost pressures, regulatory changes and market dynamics are behind this trend.
Chiropractors' shift toward the group model seen in the broader healthcare sector

Rising spending on chiropractic care highlights its value. Consumers continue to spend on chiropractic treatment in 2023 despite inflation, underscoring the field's shift to mainstream medical treatment.
Many patients consider chiropractic treatments as a supplement to traditional care
Rising incomes in recent years have allowed more patients to fit chiropractic exams into routine medical care.
Chiropractors must stay informed in an evolving regulatory environment
Ongoing changes related to reimbursements, patient privacy and data security create challenges, but compliance is crucial to secure reimbursements and avoid fines.
Chiropractic clinics rely on out-of-pocket payments more than any other revenue source
Insurance limitations restricting access and affordable exam fees translate into many self-pay patients.
Routine chiropractic exams are the hallmark of the industry
Chiropractors depend on patients receiving routine adjustments for the bulk of their billings.
The distribution of chiropractic practices mirrors population trends
Patients living in areas with dense populations have the most access to chiropractic care, while those in rural ones could struggle to find treatment.
Chiropractic practices favor dense, suburban areas
High concentrations of chiropractic clinics are found in metro areas where practices have access to large patient pools.
Alternatives to chiropractic care put pressure on the industry
Patients can find pain relief options through traditional healthcare approaches or at-home options, making it challenging for practices to build patient volumes.
Patients value a relationship with their chiropractor
Chiropractic clinics dedicated to building trust with patients are less likely to lose patients to their competitors.
Fragmentation currently characterizes the chiropractic field. Even as consolidation activity ramps up, independent chiropractors operating solo represent more than half of the industry.

Changing dynamics in the industry are influencing profit. An evolving regulatory landscape and operating challenges strain profit growth, while an uptick in consolidation activity creates a mismatch in earnings between group and solo practices.
How chiropractic clinics navigate inflation determines their bottom line
Clinics must strike a balance between higher prices for supplies and the cost of exam fees to maintain profit.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Uninsured individuals seek chiropractor's affordable treatment for back pain given the high costs of traditional healthcare treatment.
A competitive job market seen post-COVID led many employers to rethink their benefits packages to attract employees.
Other payment sources include workers' compensation payments and personal injury payouts.
Medicare coverage of chiropractic varies by state, but usually involves strict coverage restrictions, limiting how Medicare reimbursements to practices.

products_and_services.product_description: Demand for general chiropractic care clinics results from growing acceptance of chiropractic services, expanded insurance coverage and reduced costs compared to conventional medical treatment. General care is estimated to account for nearly two-thirds of industry revenue.
Other services offered by chiropractic clinics.
Family clinics offer treatment tailored to children and expectant mothers during pregnancy as patients seeking alternatives to traditional treatments increase.
The image shows a pie chart with the percentage 7.7% which seems to represent the share of sports and rehabilitation chiropractic care services in the industry.

tier_1_suppliers: Medical Supplies Wholesaling in the US
Sporting Goods Wholesaling in the US
Electronic Medical Records Systems in the US
tier_1_buyers: Health & Medical Insurance in the US
tier_2_buyers: Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Representing the largest source of revenue, out-of-pocket payments account for an estimated 41.6% of industry revenue in 2023.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Access and Scope Determine Reimbursements from Private Insurers
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Payments from private health insurance providers account for an estimated 30.4% of industry revenue in 2023.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Medicare and Medicaid Coverage Restrictions Limit Reimbursements
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Medicare and Medicaid payments account for an estimated 30.4% in 2023.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Securing Additional Revenue Streams is Challenging
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Other revenue sources include workers' compensation payments, personal injury payouts and product sales.

business_locations.location_description: Regions like the Rocky Mountains and Plains are less populated, translating to limited access to healthcare professionals, including chiropractors.

More than one-quarter of the nation's population resides in the Southeast region. Since the distribution of clinics in the industry closely follows population trends, this region comprises nearly one-quarter of chiropractic practices.
The West also contains many chiropractic clinics, as the region's large population brings more patients into offices.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Chiropractors must follow the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) regulations.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Anti-Kickback Statute and Physician Self-Referral Laws
regulations_points.regulation_description: The federal Anti-Kickback Statute prohibits the exchange of anything of value.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) makes payments to participating chiropractors.
Chiropractors must follow the licensing requirements of their state.
Chiropractors must graduate from one of eighteen chiropractic schools accredited by the Council on Chiropractic Education.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Practices rely on a staff of licensed chiropractors, assistants and nonclinical employees.

basis_points.basis_title: Alternatives to chiropractic care put pressure on the industry
basis_points.basis_description: Patients can find pain relief options through traditional healthcare approaches or at-home options.

basis_points.basis_title: Patients value a relationship with their chiropractor
basis_points.basis_description: Chiropractic clinics dedicated to building trust with patients are less likely to lose patients to their competitors.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Fragmentation is the status quo in chiropractic care
concentration_points.concentration_description: The chiropractic field comprises a large mix of group, solo and franchise models.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation costs depend on the scope of services
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation costs account for an estimated 1.7% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Chiropractors Feel the Sting of Inflation as Purchase Costs Rise
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs account for an estimated 8.5% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit Struggles in a Post-COVID Landscape
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit will account for an estimated 18.4% of revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Practices rely on a staff of licensed chiropractors, assistants and nonclinical employees.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patents and patent concentration
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.
Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The COVID-19 pandemic creates a challenging environment
volatility_points.volatility_description: The pandemic introduced unprecedented challenges into the broader healthcare sector and didn't spare chiropractic clinics.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Chiropractic care can be an affordable alternative
volatility_points.volatility_description: A patient's income and insurance status are the main factors determining what medical services they will seek out.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: General Chiropractic Care Remains the Prominent Service Segment
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Demand for general chiropractic care clinics results from growing acceptance of chiropractic services.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Specialized clinics and specialized care are expanding
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Chiropractic colleges offer specialized courses to meet the increasing demand for niche services.

FAQs.question: How has external competition impacted growth in the number of clients and visits?
FAQs.answer: Chiropractors must compete with competition from alternatives to care including pain medication and yoga.

FAQs.question: How does your company market its services to the wider community?
FAQs.answer: Chiropractors must compete with their field's reputation.

FAQs.question: How can you encourage visits from individuals who lack health insurance?
FAQs.answer: Some industry operators offer payment plans to attract clients.

FAQs.question: Is your company geographically positioned in communities where there is a strong need?
FAQs.answer: Chiropractors typically operate in highly populated areas where there is strong demand.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
FAQs.answer: Some chiropractors have invested in digital record keeping and communication software.

FAQs.question: Have you pursued digital marketing techniques as a way to attract customers?
FAQs.answer: Chiropractors can engage in many forms of online promotion.

FAQs.question: Have any new mandates, as a result of healthcare reform, expanded your client base?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare reform has allowed more chiropractors to accept insurances.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met? How has your company adapted to health and safety requirements amid the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Chiropractors must be board-certified to prevent causing harm to patients.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: Some chiropractors have looked toward consolidation as a means of reducing costs.

FAQs.question: How has the COVID-19 (coronavirus) impacted your company's profitability?
FAQs.answer: The coronavirus pandemic created additional operating costs for many alternative healthcare providers.

FAQs.question: What steps can you take to promote chiropractic practice and your clinic? How can you demonstrate the efficacy of chiropractic techniques?
FAQs.answer: Many healthcare sources refer patients and residents to companies as a result of a provider's reputation.

FAQs.question: Are there hospitals nearby that you can reach out to in order to glean referrals? How populated is the area your current location occupies?
FAQs.answer: Chiropractors in the US tend to cluster in highly populated urban and suburban areas.

FAQs.question: How do you educate patients? How do you educate your community? How effective are your attempts at building relationships with patients?
FAQs.answer: Patient and community education encourages confidence in chiropractors.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor changes in disposable income? Have you experienced decreased demand as unemployment has risen amid the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Industry services are typically paid for as out-of-pocket direct patient costs.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your clientele participates in sports? What does an increasing number of health-conscious consumers mean for you?
FAQs.answer: Some sports have higher injury risks than others.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your patients are adults aged 50 and over? How has your company implemented safety protocols for COVID-19 (coronavirus).
FAQs.answer: Adults aged 50 and older represent the most at-risk population for coronavirus.
